comments.commentBody: Is the Times trying to imply that we DON'T live in a meritocracy?  I'm shocked!!!

The upmost in cronyism is when Bloomberg's daughter is given the helm of a new school newly built for her to lead (on Atlantic Ave and Brooklyn Ave. in Kings County.) Power corrupts and absolute power (purchase of a 3rd term) corrupts absolutely.  There was time when the populace could get fair treatment if they worked for the city where meritocracy prevailed.  With the Bloomberg administration, one must be young, gifted, white and connected to others who are young, gifted and . . .
Bloomberg is also known for having the lowest number of minorities in any citywide office, so this doesn't surprise me at all.
Gee, how did I get this internship?  The next generation of self-absorbed, over-privleged prevaricators in training.  An internship for an 8th grader?  Some country.
I guess Mr Douthat overlooked this area in his commentary about the pitiful state of downtrodden unselected coservatives due to affirmative action.
Hey NY Times - How does #42 get away with "Kikesville"?  Especially when your "report as inappropriate" button doesn't work?

The fact that there were only 450 applicants for 152 internships tells the whole story.  Many viable internship positions get ten to a hundred times more applicants per internship position.  In this case there were only 3 applicants for every internship.  That means there is not much broad-based recruitment or advertising going on for these positions.  In other words there is a covert attempt to keep the base of applicants from the same sources it has been getting them from year to year.  Apparently that applicant pool comes most from the elite friends of the mayor's office via word-of-mouth PR.  I would like for Bloomberg to explain what efforts his office makes to recruit their pool of intern applicants.  More importantly I want to hear what changes the mayor's office plans to make in future years to broaden their intern applicant base.  They should be shooting for a minimum pool of 15200 applicants instead of 450.
Wow...that's why I didn't get it this summer or why my children may not have the possibility. Maybe I should change names, change my fate in wealth.

I'm cynical, but I'm a slouch compared to some of the people who've left comments here.

Even if it's not earth-shattering, of course it's significant that there are so many well-connected interns working for the Mayor's Office. As explained, it's a valuable resume credential that is not available to many other promising young people (and how many poor and lower-middle class youths can afford to work for nothing?)

As for the taking three months to respond to the FOIA request and the failure of the Administration official to respond to questions,

For Shame!

But I lost respect for the mayor after his term-limits flip-flop.

On the other hand, the deeper and deeper entrenchment of more and more wealth in fewer and fewer hands in this country has paralyzed the democratic process.

I used to live just yards away from a warning siren meant to alert the populace in the event of a nuclear meltdown at the Indian Point Power Plant, some 40 miles to the south of us. At first, beginning around the early 80s, the apparatus worked well. It literally shook the house every couple of months. My cats disappeared for days afterward.

We were always notified via the local paper when the blasts were scheduled, always at 11 a.m. on occasional Tuesdays. If we were home, we shut the windows and held our ears, to not much avail. It went on for about five full minutes, in case we didn't get the message.

As the years went by the tests became fewer. It turned out the sirens just weren't working much of the time. I didn't really care, because where were we going to escape to? The only really good decontamination shelter was at West Point, for the military brass, and another about 30 miles away in the county seat.

We haven't heard much about nuclear disasters since the Cold War ended. Who among us of a certain generation can forget the "duck and cover" drills in schools for when the Bomb hit? Even as seven-year-olds we knew it was a big joke.

I am glad you wrote about nuclear safety, because frankly I hadn't really been thinking much about it. But you are right to bring it up. The only time we hear about it where I live is when the occasional worker dies in a freak accident, or thousands of fish get sucked into the reactor with the river water. Hudson Riverkeeper is an environmental action group which has tried mightily for years to shut the plant down - but New York City needs the juice, and we know how that goes. But, since the sirens malfunctioned, you have to wonder about the safety of the actual plant. It's one of those God-awful scenarios nobody wants to think about.

Seeing the incompetence and greed evidenced in the Deepwater Horizon disaster, you are right to bring this to public attention. Thank you, Bob Herbert, for a very sobering and thought-provoking column.
The energy policy being proposed here is denial of any American energy.  Production of energy is to be outsourced.  There go the jobs, to be replaced by permanent UI.

Nuclear Power is quite safe and Bob Herbert's thinking would keep us in the energy "Stone Age".

The French, The Japanese and Americans have had safe, productive and clean Nuclear Power for decades now.

Nuclear Power has proven to be the cleanest and safest way to produce the most electicity possible for the least cost.

The United States has numerous safe, efficient and clean Nuclear Power Plants all over the nation not to mention as the power plants on board Nuclear Powered Submarines.

Although I agree with you that we must tread carefully in installing nuclear power plants in our country, many European countries as well as Canada have done so with successful results.
It would be helpful to your readers if you could gather some of the data from other countries and report the pros and cons. Our country especially, must have strict regulations in place should any such plants be built and attention to the refuse problems be thoroughly investigated.
Let us not give up on alternative energy possibilities without examining their possibilities. They may well be needed in the future.

Sorry Mr. Herbert, You are comparing and contrasting "Apples and Oranges". Oil Rigs are inherently safe as are Nuclear Power Plants.

With your "Canary In A Coal Mine", "Nervous Nell" fearful outlook---We might as well go back to Horse and Buggy and Wind Power.

No, Mr. Herbert, your ideas may make for good liberal "Copy" and Fodder but Your Ideas on "Shutting Down" Progress is not realistic or practical.

We Need the Energy that Nuclear Power Produces and for the forseeable future we Need the Oil that we obtain through Offshore Oil Wells.

Bob, you're so wrong here I don't know where to begin.

Is it that China just passed the us in overall power consumption, and leads in the construction of new solar, wind, and nuclear energy, and folks are going to care less about what we think in the future?

Is it your own recent column about how greatness is slipping away from us?

Go learn about the Bechtel/Babcock & Wilcox alliance to build small-scale nuclear plants, based on the mPower reactor.

Better still, go visit the B&W factory and talk to their executives - and then come back and talk to us.

What Obama should be doing is looking to fast-track this technology, and add incremental capacity to existing nuclear plant sites. About a 30% increase to the base capacity.

We need the jobs...

...though without the jobs - we may soon not need the energy.

Or is future employment in our energy sector secure - based on pushing brooms along a beach?

Sorry for the bluntness.

For several decades, we've made 20% of our electricity from nuclear power without a single fatality.

Coal-fired power plants produce so much air pollution that they kill some 10,000 Americans every year--and warm the planet with billions of tons of carbon dioxide every year. Why then is Bob Herbert more alarmed about the dangers of nuclear power than about the dangers of coal? It's because we humans fear most what we don't understand.

So let the debate begin regarding the safety of this important source of energy - nuclear power plants.
Weigh the pros and cons and publicize same. Provide the necessary information/critical research from knowledgeable sources.
All I know is that my nephew, the one with the PhD in Physics/Nuclear Energy, says it is perfectly safe.
Would he mislead his favorite Aunt? To be continued.
